title: Missing Number In Arithmetic Progression
description: You are given an array of integers that are in arithmetic progression but are missing one number. The array is sorted in ascending order. Your task is to find the missing number in the progression. An arithmetic progression is defined as a sequence of numbers such that the difference between consecutive terms is constant.
input_format: An array of integers nums representing the sequence of integers in arithmetic progression with one missing number.
output_format: An integer representing the missing number in the arithmetic progression.
constraints: The numbers in nums are distinct.

examples.explanation: The arithmetic progression has a common difference of 2. The missing number is 9.
The common difference is 2. The missing number is 7.

hints: Calculate the common difference by finding the average of the first and last term divided by the length of the array.
Use a loop to check for the missing number based on the expected arithmetic progression.

title: Minimum Absolute Difference
description: Given an array of integers, find the minimum absolute difference between any two elements in the array. An absolute difference between two integers x and y is defined as |x - y|. You need to return the minimum absolute difference found in the array. If the array contains fewer than 2 elements, return 0.
output_format: An integer representing the minimum absolute difference.

examples.explanation: The absolute differences are |3 - 8| = 5, |3 - 15| = 12, |3 - 17| = 14, |8 - 15| = 7, |8 - 17| = 9, and |15 - 17| = 2. The minimum is 2.
The absolute differences are |1 - 2| = 1, |1 - 3| = 2, |1 - 4| = 3, |2 - 3| = 1, |2 - 4| = 2, and |3 - 4| = 1. The minimum is 1.

hints: Sorting the array can help find the minimum absolute difference.

title: Leetflex Banned Accounts
description: In a social media application, you are tasked to find the number of users who have been banned. Each user has a unique identifier, and there is a list of banned identifiers. Your goal is to return the count of unique banned user identifiers in the input list.
input_format: A list of integers representing user identifiers and a list of integers representing banned identifiers.
output_format: An integer representing the count of unique banned user identifiers.

examples.explanation: Both identifiers 1 and 2 are banned, so the count of unique banned user identifiers is 2.
Only identifier 3 is banned, so the count of unique banned user identifiers is 1.

hints: Use a set to track unique banned identifiers.
Iterate through the user_ids and count only those found in the banned_ids.
